"The program itself promises to be a brilliant radio series bringing to light

With a poignant simplicity and disciplined g randeur the opening installment of this

and then quietly put the telling question to all of us: What is our generation doing?-*

"The Jeffersonian Heritage" is a 13-week half-hour series dealing with the life,
times, principles and philosophy of Thomas Jefferson* However, its purpose is nob
biographical, but rather to show how Jeffersonian ideal3 have guided generations of

(June Bundy, Billboard, Sept. 20, 1952)
"Radio’s evaluation of Thomas Jefferson’s contributions to the free world—the
highly touted series produced by the National Assn, of Educational Broadcasters un¬
der a grant from the Ford Foundation—got away to an impressive start (Sunday, Sept.
14), to suggest that this series will have steady, and sharpened impact*
"A little pretentious and self-conscious in its scripting at the very start,
the premiere program got into proper dramatic focus very soon, however, by virtue
of its subject matter and Claude Rains* fine performance as Jefferson. The meat
and sincerity in this program, the easy though serious way in which it was presented
as veil as the sterling quality of the acting performances, type this as a highly
important series. It should be ’must1 listening for adults as well as all schoolrooms.
"Program was a combined narration-dramatization format, which had drama, bite,
and vigor." (Variety, Sept. 17, 1952)
"The NAEB should be mighty proud of the job producer Frank Papp and his staff
did on their ’Heffersonian Heritage3 series. The quality of production and script
are radio at its almost forgotten best—reminiscent of the glorious days of the
old Columbia Workshop...." (Ted Orson. Radio Daily, Oct. 21, 1952)
